node.title: Officials reject fake news articles claiming Govt 'approved euthanasia for COVID patients'
node.description: "There is no truth to this claim."
node.content: ["The Ministry of Health says there is no truth to claims that a law has been passed to specifically allow doctors to decide whether to euthanise COVID-19 patients.\n", "Examples of the claims on social media are observable\u202fhere\u202f\u202fand\u202fhere\u202f.\u202f", "Many of the posts share a screenshot of a headline from the Gateway Pundit, which reads, 'New Zealand Government Approves Euthanasia for COVID Patients.'\u00a0", "Similar posts share screenshots and links seen\u202fhere\u202fand\u202fhere\u202ffrom the Catholic Herald which bears the headline, 'New Zealand okays euthanasia for COVID patients.' \u202f", "The virality of the claim coincided with New Zealand making assisted dying legally available from November 7, 2021, per the End of Life Choice Act 2019.\u00a0", "It came into effect a year after New Zealanders voted in favour of the legislation in a public referendum.\u00a0", "In December, grassroots group Defend NZ, which opposes the End of Life Choice Act, published an article that appears to be a catalyst for the claims spreading on social media.", "The article expressed concern assisted dying laws could be used \"as tools to resolve such a serious crisis\" as a rise in COVID-19 hospitalisations. It also published part of an exchange with the Ministry of Health, in which a spokesperson said a circumstance might arise in which a person with COVID-19 could be eligible for assisted suicide.\u00a0", "Blair Cunningham, a senior media advisor for the health ministry, told Reuters it was not accurate for social media posts to suggest the legislation was specifically introduced to euthanise COVID-19 patients.", "\"There is no truth to this claim,\" Cunningham said in an email.", "Cunningham repeated the same statement published by Defend NZ, which said: \"Eligibility is determined on a case-by-case basis; therefore, the ministry cannot make definitive statements about who is eligible. In\u202fsome\u202fcircumstances a person with COVID-19\u202fmay be\u202feligible for assisted dying.\"", "Such eligibility requirements, Cunnigham explained, \"are clear\u2026 These include that a person must have a terminal illness that is likely to end their life within six months\".", "Other requirements also stipulate a patient must be 18 years or over, a citizen or permanent resident of New Zealand, experiencing unbearable suffering that cannot be relieved in a manner that the person considers tolerable, and must be competent to make an informed decision about assisted dying.", "According to official guidance\u202f(see the section on process for accessing assisted dying), at least two doctors and, if required, a psychiatrist must assess a person\u2019s competency to decide on assisted death.\u00a0Additional guidance (see page 4) says, \"the person must be the one to raise assisted dying with someone in their health care team. A health professional cannot suggest it as an option\".\u00a0", "More information on the assisted dying process in New Zealand is reviewable\u202fhere\u202f\u202fand here.", "Missing context. Representatives for the Ministry of Health say New Zealand has not approved euthanasia for COVID-19 patients if doctors decide the patient is unlikely to survive - but say in some circumstances, a person with COVID-19 may be eligible for assisted dying.", "Reuters"]
